storyContent.tagHTML: We begin counting the lives of Bhagwän Mahävir from his life as Nayasär, when he attained self-realization (Samyaktva). Notable lives are Nayasär (life #1), Marichi (life #3), Vishvabhuti (life #16), Triprushtha Väsudev (life #18), Priyamitra Chakravarti (life #23) and Nandan Muni (life #25). As Nandan Muni, he attained Tirthankar Näm-karma. He was born as a Dev in his 26th life. In his 27th and final life, he was born as Vardhamän Mahävir.

About 2600 years ago, religion in India was marked by a rigid caste system and animal sacrifices. Into this world, Mahävir was born. It is believed that all Tirthankars are born into the Kshatriya (warrior) class, to a royal family, to help them understand that there is no permanent happiness in material comfort.

Queen Trishalä, like all Tirthankar’s mothers, saw 14 auspicious dreams. When her husband, King Siddhärtha, consulted scholars, they proclaimed that she would give birth to a Tirthankar. While in the womb, the baby remained still to not cause his mother pain. Realizing her worry, he decided not to renounce the world as long as his parents were alive.

Mahävir was born in 599 B.C. on a day celebrated today as Mahävir Janma Kalyänak. He had an older brother named Nandivardhan. Soon after his birth, Indra (king of heavenly gods) performed a divine birth ceremony on Mount Meru. Because the kingdom's prosperity had increased since his conception, the baby was named Vardhamän, meaning 'ever-increasing'.

At age 28, after his parents passed away, Mahävir prepared for renunciation. He spent a year giving away all his worldly possessions. At age 30, on the tenth day of the dark half of Kärtak, he left the palace. Under an Ashok tree, he took the vows of a monk, plucking out his hair in five handfuls in a ritual known as Panchmushthi loch. He immediately attained Manah-paryav Jnän, the knowledge of the thoughts of all living beings.

For twelve and a half years, Mahävir practiced severe austerities. He faced many afflictions, including being tormented by the demon Sulpäni, who failed to break his meditation. He enlightened a venomous cobra named Chandkaushik with his compassion. He broke a fast of nearly six months by accepting food from Chandanbälä, a princess sold into slavery. In his final affliction, a cowherd plugged sharp grass pegs into his ears, causing excruciating pain which he bore patiently.

After 12.5 years of intense meditation, on the bank of the river Rujuvälukä, Mahävir destroyed all his destructive (Ghäti) karmas and attained Keval-jnän (omniscience). The gods built a divine assembly hall, a Samavasaran, for his first sermon. He traveled and preached for 30 years.

At a great sacrifice in Päväpuri, a learned priest named Indrabhuti Gautam went to challenge Mahävir. Instead, Mahävir resolved his deepest spiritual doubts without being asked. Indrabhuti and ten other scholars, along with their 4400 disciples, became Mahävir's disciples. The eleven scholars became his chief disciples, or Ganadhars.

At the age of 72, in 527 B.C., Mahävir gave his final sermon in Päväpuri. On the new-moon night of the month of Äso, he shed his remaining karmas and his soul achieved Nirväna (liberation). To mark the extinguishing of the 'light' of his knowledge from the world, the kings present lit earthen lamps, a tradition that continues as the festival of Diwäli.

events.title: Self-Realization
events.description: The soul destined to be Mahävir attains Samyaktva (self-realization) in his life as Nayasär.

events.title: Attaining Tirthankar Näm-karma
events.description: As Nandan Muni in his 25th life, the soul performs austerities that earn him the destiny of becoming a Tirthankar.

events.title: Auspicious Dreams
events.description: Queen Trishalä sees 14 auspicious dreams, foretelling the birth of a great soul.

events.title: The Birth of Vardhamän
events.description: Mahävir is born and named Vardhamän. Indra performs his divine birth ceremony (Janma Abhishek).

events.title: The Great Hero
events.description: At age eight, Vardhamän fearlessly overcomes challenges posed by a god, earning the name 'Mahävir' (Great Hero).

events.title: The Great Renunciation (Dikshä)
events.description: At age 30, Mahävir renounces the world, performs the Panchmushthi loch, and takes the five great vows.

events.title: Affliction by Sulpäni
events.description: A wicked Yaksha named Sulpäni tries to terrorize Mahävir with various tortures but fails to break his meditation.

events.title: Enlightening Chandkaushik
events.description: Mahävir calms a fearsome, venomous cobra named Chandkaushik with his compassion, leading the cobra to repentance.

events.title: Breaking the Fast
events.description: Mahävir breaks a fast of nearly six months, accepting food from the enslaved princess Chandanbälä who met his specific conditions.

events.title: The Last Calamity
events.description: A cowherd, angry at the silent Mahävir, hammers sharp grass pegs into his ears, an agony he endures with equanimity.

events.title: Keval-jnän (Omniscience)
events.description: After 12.5 years of penance, Mahävir attains absolute knowledge on the banks of the river Rujuvälukä.

events.title: Establishing the Sangh
events.description: Mahävir converts 11 learned Brahmins, led by Indrabhuti Gautam, who become his chief disciples (Ganadhars).

events.title: Liberation (Nirväna)
events.description: At age 72, in Päväpuri, Mahävir gives his final sermon and attains Nirväna. The Festival of Lights, Diwäli, is lit to commemorate this event.

charactersData.name: Bhagawän Mahävir
charactersData.description: The 24th and final Tirthankar of this time cycle. Born as Prince Vardhamän, he became a 'Great Hero' known for his courage, compassion, and ultimate self-control.

charactersData.name: King Siddhärtha & Queen Trishalä
charactersData.description: The royal parents of Mahävir. Queen Trishalä's 14 auspicious dreams foretold his birth.

charactersData.name: Indra
charactersData.description: The king of the heavenly gods, who played a significant role in celebrating Mahävir's key life events (Kalyänaks) and testing his courage.

charactersData.name: Nandivardhan
charactersData.description: Mahävir's older brother, who, out of love, asked him to delay his renunciation for two years after their parents' death.

charactersData.name: Chandkaushik
charactersData.description: A highly venomous cobra who was transformed by Mahävir's compassion, repented his violent nature, and attained a heavenly birth.

charactersData.name: Chandanbälä
charactersData.description: A princess who was sold into slavery. She had the great fortune of being the one to break Mahävir's long fast of five months and twenty-five days.

charactersData.name: Indrabhuti Gautam
charactersData.description: A learned Brahmin scholar whose pride led him to challenge Mahävir. He was instantly converted and became Mahävir's first and chief disciple (Ganadhar).

quizData.question: In which of his previous lives did Mahävir's soul attain Tirthankar Näm-karma?
quizData.answer: In his 25th life as Nandan Muni.

quizData.question: What was Mahävir's birth name, meaning 'ever-increasing prosperity'?
What is the name of the ritual where Mahävir plucked out his hair in five handfuls at his initiation?
Which venomous cobra did Mahävir pacify with his compassion?
What was the last major physical affliction Mahävir endured before attaining omniscience?
quizData.answer: A cowherd hammered sharp grass pegs into his ears.

quizData.question: Where did Mahävir attain Keval-jnän (omniscience)?
quizData.answer: On the banks of the river Rujuvälukä.

quizData.question: Who was the first Ganadhar (chief disciple) of Bhagawän Mahävir?
In which city did Mahävir attain Nirväna (liberation)?
Which festival of lights commemorates the Nirväna of Bhagawän Mahävir?
How many dreams did Queen Trishalä see according to the Shvetämbar tradition?
What is the name of the scripture that contains Bhagawän Mahävir's last sermon?
At what age did Mahävir renounce his worldly life to become a monk?
What special knowledge did Mahävir attain immediately after his initiation (Dikshä)?
quizData.answer: Manah-paryav Jnän (the ability to know the thoughts of others).

quizData.question: Who was the wicked Yaksha (demon) who tried and failed to torture Mahävir in a temple?
For how long did Bhagawän Mahävir's final sermon last?
Why did Mahävir decide not to take renunciation while his parents were alive?
quizData.answer: While in the womb, he sensed his mother's anxiety when he was still and decided not to cause his parents pain by leaving them.

quizData.question: To which social class are all Tirthankars said to be born?
Who was Mahävir's older brother who asked him to postpone his renunciation?
Who performed Bhagawän Mahävir's divine birth ceremony (Janma Abhishek) on Mount Meru?
quizData.answer: Indra, the king of the heavenly gods.

quizData.question: After the cobra disguise failed, what did the heavenly god disguise himself as to test Mahävir?
quizData.answer: As an ordinary child to join the other children in a game.

children.name: Birth to King Siddhärtha & Queen Trishalä
Vow to stay until parents' death

graphicsData.title: The Queen's Dreams
graphicsData.description: Queen Trishalä sees 14 auspicious dreams, which scholars interpret as a sign that she will give birth to a Tirthankar, a great spiritual guide for the world.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A montage of 14 symbols like a lion, elephant, and the sun, representing Queen Trishalä's dreams.

graphicsData.title: The Fearless Prince
graphicsData.description: A heavenly god, disguised as a terrifying cobra, tries to scare the young Prince Vardhamän, who calmly and fearlessly handles the snake, proving his immense courage.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A young Prince Vardhamän gently holding a large cobra, showing no fear.

graphicsData.title: The Great Renunciation
graphicsData.description: At age 30, Prince Vardhamän renounces his royal life, performing the 'Panchmushthi loch' by plucking out all his hair as a symbol of detachment from the body.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Mahävir sits under a tree, calmly plucking out his hair as he begins his life as a monk.

graphicsData.title: Compassion for a Cobra
graphicsData.description: Mahävir faces the deadly cobra Chandkaushik. Instead of fighting, he radiates compassion, which calms the snake's rage and leads it to a life of penance.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Mahävir stands in meditation as a large cobra looks up at him, its aggressive posture softening.

graphicsData.title: The Final Obstacle
graphicsData.description: In his final test of endurance, a furious cowherd hammers sharp grass pegs into Mahävir's ears. He bears the excruciating pain with perfect equanimity.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Mahävir stands in deep meditation while a cowherd angrily forces pegs into his ears.

graphicsData.title: The Light of Omniscience
graphicsData.description: After 12.5 years of penance, Mahävir destroys all his karmic obscurations and attains Keval-jnän (absolute knowledge), becoming an all-knowing Arihant.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Mahävir sits in meditation under a tree, glowing with a divine light symbolizing the attainment of omniscience.
